briefdescription.para: An custom type representing a single voxel in an occupancy map.

detaileddescription.para:
This is represented as a pair containing:
pose_t: The coordinates of the voxel (x, y, time). Where Time is a physical dimension
double: A double representing the size of the voxel in meters.
The coordinate is at the 2D (x,y) geometric center of the grid cell, and extends vertical by 1 unit time
Constraint: maximum permitted angle between 2 Nodes
Constraint: maximum permitted curvature between 3 Nodes
Constraint: maximum permitted longitudinal acceleration between 2 Nodes
Constraint: maximum permitted longitudinal jerk between 3 Nodes
Constraint: maximum permitted distance between 2 Nodes
Constraint: minimum permitted distance between 2 Nodes
Constraint: maximum time interval between 2 Nodes
Constraint: maximum time
Specifies if the RRT is 2D or 3D, initialized to 2D, no temporal
Flag to indicate the RRT is complete
An Admissible solution exists to the destination node
Maximum number of of iterations, protect against infinite loops when no admissability
Initial heading of the RRT at the origin node
Maximum number of admissible trajectories
list of admissible end/destination nodes
Lower Left Corner of the Operating Region
Upper Right Corner of the Operating Region
Origin of the RRT
Destination of the RRT
After this many sequential nodes in occupied space, we stop and assume a non-admissible trajectory

briefdescription.para: An Occupancy Map (Grid) represented as a simple list of occupied voxels.

detaileddescription.para: This is represented as a vector of occupancy_t, where each element (pose_t) present in the list implies occupied space/time. Space is assumed to be free if not present in the list.

briefdescription.para: Searches the adjacency list for the nearest node to the given node.

parameterdescription.para: The given node we want to reference the search against
if true will return 3D nearest (z-plane beiing time). otherwise only cares about x,y

simplesect.para: Excludes/omits destination node from search
Pointer to the Graph-Node which is nearest to the handle

inbodydescription.para: Need to optimize
Ignore/do not consider any destination nodes or nodes with forward connections to destination nodes
Check if this node has any forward connections to destination nodes
Make sure we're not comparing the handle to itself

briefdescription.para: Calculates the 2D eculidian distance between two nodes.

parameterdescription.para: The first node
The second node
if true will return 3D distance. Otherwise only cares about x,y

simplesect.para: Eculidian distance between the two nodes

briefdescription.para: Calculates the angle (in radians) between two nodes.

parameterdescription.para: The first node
The second node

simplesect.para: Angle between the two nodes
The angle is calculated as the delta between the pose of the reference node and the eculidean position of the handle
It is assumed that setting of the pose of the handle will be done after/elsewhere

briefdescription.para: Calculates an edge weight based upon kinematic cost constraints.

parameterdescription.para: The first node
The second node

simplesect.para: Edge weight based upon kinematic cost constraints

inbodydescription.para: Calculate a composite back-edge weight based on kinematic cost

briefdescription.para: Checks if the constraints (distance, angle, interval) are satisfied between a given node and its nearest neighbor.

simplesect.para: This is only intended to be used by the Build function since it only checks against the nearest neighbor

parameterdescription.para: The given node we want to check constraints for

simplesect.para: Returns true if the constraints are satisfied, false otherwise

briefdescription.para: Applies/Updates node parameters to ensure the constraints are satisfied.

simplesect.para: Also ensures the node is within the operating region

parameterdescription.para: The given node we want to force constraints upon

inbodydescription.para: connects our new node to the nearest while also destroying the fwd connection in the old back link to prevent loop-back in RRT
Impose Spatial Absolute constraints (Angle and Distance)
Impose Dynamic constraints (Curvature)
Impose Dynamic Temporal Constraints (Longitudinal Acceleration/Jerk) - Not implemented yet

briefdescription.para: Checks if the RRT gaph has a Node near the desired destination and said node is within the constraints relative to the destination.

simplesect.para: Sets this->cmplt = true if the destination is reached within constraints

inbodydescription.para: Make sure this graph isn't already complete `
Create Dummy end-node with time of zero
Find the nearest Node to end
Update the destination time to be equal to the nearest node's time
Grab the preceeding node to nearest
Stash these in case the heuristic fails and we need to revert
Calculate parameters between end and end/second_nearest
Check if the node meets the spatial constraints (intentionally ignoring angle, just seeing if its close enough)
Heuristic: lets smooth out the end and make a nice "landing path" to the destination
Check constraints against second nearest (doubling the constraints values (Assuming time is fine, if it werrent we wouldnt be in this method))
Reposition nearest to be at the midpoint between the preceeding and the end node
Double check that the second nearest node is still within constraints
Formally add the dummy destination node to the graph
list this node as an admissible destination node
Put humpty dumpty back together again
Put humpty dumpty back together again

briefdescription.para: Calculates the 2D (x,y) curvature between 3 Nodes using the Menger Curvature formula.

simplesect.para: Returns 0.0F if the points are collinear or any pointer is null

parameterdescription.para: The first node
The second node
The third node

inbodydescription.para: Null-pointer guard: if any input is null, return 0
Calculate the Menger Curature given three nodes

briefdescription.para: Calculates the 2D (x,y) curvature between 3 Points using the Menger Curvature formula.

simplesect.para: Returns 0.0F if the points are collinear or any pointer is null

parameterdescription.para: distance between first and second node
distance between second and third node
distance between first and third node

briefdescription.para: Adjusts spataial parameters of the current node to ensure curvature constraints are satisfied.

parameterdescription.para: The current node we want to constrain

inbodydescription.para: Check that the handle has two sequential back connections via checking nullptr If we do not have 2 back connections, we're by the origin and only the max angle constraint applies
Determine the sign of the curvature
Get coordinates

briefdescription.para: Calculates the maximum permitted spatial constraints based on absolute limit params and applies it to the current node.

parameterdescription.para: The current node we want to constrain
The nearest node to the current node

inbodydescription.para: Apply Absolute Scaling Constraints Ensure angle change is within limits relative to the previous node's heading/pose
Need to ensure time never runs backwards
Update the Node with the new coordinates which meet absolute constraints

briefdescription.para: Aligns the heading of the current node to be tangent to the menger curvature from the previous 2 nodes.

parameterdescription.para: The current node we want to align
The x coordinate of the center of curvature
The y coordinate of the center of curvature

inbodydescription.para: Calculate the tangent heading at the node given the center of curvature
Tangent is perpendicular to radius vector

briefdescription.para: Calculates the longitudinal acceleration between two nodes.

parameterdescription.para: The current node
The reference node

simplesect.para: The longitudinal acceleration between the two nodes (units per time^2)

inbodydescription.para: Calculate the longitudinal acceleration based on back connection nodes

briefdescription.para: Calculates the longitudinal jerk between two nodes.

parameterdescription.para: The current node
The first reference node

simplesect.para: The longitudinal jerk between the two nodes (units per time per time^3)

inbodydescription.para: Calculate the longitudinal jerk based on back connection nodes

briefdescription.para: Adjusts spataial and temporal parameters of the current node to ensure longitudinal dynamic constraints are satisfied.

parameterdescription.para: The current node

inbodydescription.para: Recompute time to satisfy Acceleration constraint Δt = [v - sqrt(v² - 2as)] / a
Recompute jerk after adjusting time
Recompute time to satisfy Jerk constraint Δt = [sqrt(3j² + 12a₀²) - 3a₀]/j for given jerk j, initial acceleration a₀, displacement s
Recompute time to satisfy Acceleration constraint Δt = [v - sqrt(v² - 2as] / a
Recompute time to satisfy Jerk constraint Δt = [sqrt(3j² + 12a₀²) - 3a₀]/j for given jerk j, initial acceleration a₀, displacement s

briefdescription.para: Compares a node (coordinates) against the occupancy map to determine if it is occupied.

parameterdescription.para: The node (coordinates) we want

simplesect.para: Returns true if the node is occupied, false otherwise

inbodydescription.para: No occupancy map provided, assume not occupied
Check if the back connection exists; if not, assume not occupied
Iterate through the occupied cubes (voxels)
Occupied bounding corner locations
Check that the node itself is not in occupied space
Check that the line segment (edge) between the node and the back link is not passing through occupied space
Line segment intersection check
Check each axis (x, y, z/time)
Line parallel to axis
Line is outside cube bounds on this axis
No intersection on this axis
Check if the valid t range overlaps with [0, 1]
Return true if the node or its connecting edge is in occupied space
Exit RRT build if too many sequential occupied nodes

briefdescription.para: Constructs/Initializes a new RRT Graph in the form of an Adjacency List.

simplesect.para: ADefault constructor, Freespaceboundaries are set to reserved values

parameterdescription.para: Optional occupancy map, if provided, will be used to check for freespace

briefdescription.para: Destroys the RRT Graph.
Builds the RRT Graph through completion.
Builds the RRT Graph One node at a time.

detaileddescription.para:
It is intended to use this function in a loop to build the RRT incrementally This will allow ther user to dynamically scale/change the constraints or update the destination
Returns true if the RRT is complete, false otherwise

inbodydescription.para: Ensure Random Node is within permissible range / operating region
Generate random points within the bounded space
Looping to ensure step call results in a new node in non-occupied space
increment iteration count
Generate Random Node within permissible range
Add the Node to the Graph
Apply Constraints, This effectively implements the RRT and also implements kinematic constraints
Check if the new node is in occupied space
If the node is occupied, delete it and try again
This iteration doesn't count because we didnt emplace a Node
Node is not occupied, placement is good
Check to see if the new node is within range of the destination
